ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Continuation of al Kitaab. Lots of grammar plus some reading, writing and speaking.
I learned how to better my reading and writing skills in Arabic with better conjugations, more forms of verbs, and overall just improving my fluency with the language; a lot of vocabulary as well!
Better grasp of Arabic grammar and reading

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A little too much focus on rules and grammar as opposed to exposure to texts and listening. I think a more immersive approach makes learning the grammar easier than memorization.

This course was really well structured, tests were fair, and information was really well taught! I do think some of the homeworks were a little unfair -- we'd have a 10 minute one one night and a 2 hour one the next -- and we definitely didn't spend as much time speaking as I'd hoped, but otherwise it was great!
Strengths: a lot of material through various media; Professor Muhammed explains everything well and is always happy to help

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are passionate about Arabic, and are ok with focusing a little on the nitpicky details, definitely. You learn a lot about Middle Eastern culture as well.

I would! Arabic 140 with Randa really furthered my Arabic knowledge a lot; I really felt like I was starting to get a good grasp of the grammar and how to talk about and understand complex topics, which is what I really wanted to do in this class.

Yes. Professor Muhammed is good at explaining difficult grammar concepts. This is probably the hardest Arabic class so far because of a lot of reading and writing and difficult grammar, but it is worth it! Just have to put in a lot of time to memorize things
